frameworkBody:
Covid Act Now worked alongside a network of research, policy, and public health experts convened by Harvard’s Global Health Institute and Edmond J. Safra Center for Ethics to develop the [Key Metrics for COVID Suppression](https://globalhealth.harvard.edu/key-metrics-for-covid-suppression-researchers-and-public-health-experts-unite-to-bring-clarity-to-key-metrics-guiding-coronavirus-response/) framework.

Central to this framework is our five-color COVID warning system, which communicates the severity of a location’s outbreak and offers corresponding guidance on mitigation efforts needed at each risk level. This facilitates a unified approach with common metrics, enabling leaders at all levels to anticipate and adequately respond to their community’s COVID spread, and informing the general public on their community’s risk to COVID. To develop this framework, we prioritized metrics vital to guiding suppression efforts that allow a community to safely reopen.
metadataTitle: Risk Levels and Key Metrics for COVID-19
metadataDescription: Understand the Risk Levels in your community and COVID Metrics: daily new cases, infection rate, positive test rate, ICU capacity used, contact tracing.

sections.sectionHeader: How COVID community risk levels are determined
sections.sectionIntro:
A location’s community risk level takes into account three metrics: total new COVID cases per 100,000 population in the past 7 days, new COVID admissions per 100,000 population in the past 7 days, and the percent of staffed inpatient beds occupied by COVID patients.

* [New COVID cases](/covid-risk-levels-metrics#weekly-new-cases) represent the current amount of COVID in a community and acts as an early warning indicator of potential increases in health system strain.
* [COVID admissions](/covid-risk-levels-metrics#COVID-admissions) and [patients with COVID](/covid-risk-levels-metrics#patients-with-covid) represent the current potential for health system strain.

To calculate the community risk level, a color or level is assigned to each of the three metrics based on their values:

* Weekly new cases: Less than 200 = Lower, and more than or equal to 200 = Higher
* Weekly hospital admissions per 100k: Less than 10 = Low, between 10 and 19.9 = Medium, and more than or equal to 20 = High. 
* Staffed inpatient beds occupied by COVID patients: Less than 10% = Low, 10% to 14.9% = Medium, and more than or equal to 15% = High

questions.answer:
Based on the CDC’s framework, we then combine the levels to get the community risk level as follows:

* If CASES are LOWER, and both HOSPITAL metrics are LOW = Community risk level is LOW
* If CASES are HIGHER, and (1) HOSPITAL metric is MEDIUM = Community risk level is HIGH
* If CASES are LOWER, and HOSPITAL metrics are NOT LOW = Community risk level is the HIGHER of the two HOSPITAL metrics
* If CASES are HIGHER = Community risk level is one level higher than the higher of the two HOSPITAL metrics. Examples below:

  * If Springfield County has HIGHER CASES, but (2) LOW HOSPITAL metrics =  Community risk level is MEDIUM
  * If Springfield County has HIGHER CASES, but (1) LOW HOSPITAL metric and (1) MEDIUM HOSPITAL metric  =  Community risk level is HIGH

[Read more details on the CDC's methodology.](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/community-levels.html)

Covid Act Now’s former COVID risk framework was developed in the summer of 2020 in response to a lack of government risk standardization in the U.S. At the time there was also limited access to testing, it was prior to any vaccination authorization, and it was before new highly infectious variants like Omicron. [Read about our former COVID risk framework.](/covid-community-level-metrics#former-risk-framework)

We remain committed to continuing to make all of our previous metrics available on our site and in our API. We acknowledge that these old metrics may remain useful to those who want to avoid infection. [Find detailed instructions on how to access those metrics here](/faq#where-are-previous-metrics).

sections.sectionIntro: **Weekly new cases is the number of new COVID cases per week per unit of population** **(we measure per 100K people).**

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
The weekly new cases number is a seven-day total of new cases, divided by every 100K people in a location. For instance, if a location has 200K people, we would divide the weekly new cases by two.

To calculate new cases, we use new positive cases [from The New York Times](https://developer.nytimes.com/covid).

Daily cases per 100K population is still visible in "Trends."

questions.question: Levels
questions.answer: Levels for weekly new cases are generally based on the [CDC’s Community Level framework](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/community-levels.html). Less than 200 cases is considered Lower, while greater than or equal to 200 cases is considered Higher.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
Our case data faces several limitations due to lack of federal reporting standards.

1. Not all states specify and report both confirmed and probable COVID cases. Confirmed cases are those that have been confirmed by PCR test and probable cases are counted by assumptions based on epidemiological evidence like antigen tests and reported symptoms. A state may report only confirmed cases, both confirmed and probable cases separately, or the two together without specification.
2. There are also inconsistencies when patients move across counties or when a patient’s treatment location is not reported.
3. At-home tests are not tracked, and therefore not represented in the data.

Credible data sources such as The New York Times (NYT) work to address these limitations by interpreting and verifying the data, and counting patients based on where they are being treated rather than where they live, when possible.

sections.sectionIntro: **Weekly COVID admissions is the number of new COVID hospital admissions per week per unit of population (we measure per 100K people).**

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
The weekly COVID admissions number is a seven-day total of new COVID admissions, divided by every 100K people in a location. We source this metric directly from the CDC's community level dataset wherever possible, and calculate it ourselves using HHS provided data wherever CDC metric data isn't available. Generally, new county-level data is ingested from the CDC metrics, while all state-level data, and county-level data from before February 24th, 2022 is calculated using HHS data.

To calculate this metric for counties, we use data [from the CDC](https://data.cdc.gov/Public-Health-Surveillance/United-States-COVID-19-Community-Levels-by-County/3nnm-4jni), which uses data from the US Department of Health and Human Services Unified Hospital Data Surveillance System. To calculate this metric for metros, we aggregate the county data using a population-weighted average. To calculate this metric for states, we use data [from the HHS](https://healthdata.gov/Hospital/COVID-19-Reported-Patient-Impact-and-Hospital-Capa/g62h-syeh) to calculate the number of admissions over the last week and then normalize that by the state’s population.

questions.question: Levels
questions.answer: Levels for weekly new admissions are generally based on the [CDC’s Community Level framework](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/community-levels.html). Less than 10 weekly new admissions is considered Low, between 10 and 19.9 is considered Medium, and greater than or equal to 20 is considered High.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
1. County-level data is only reported once a week. 
2. For counties, the data is based on the [health service area](/faq#health-service-area) the county is a part of. A county with no hospitals can still have admissions data, based on the admission rates of other hospitals within the health service area.
3. This data is closely watched by HHS, but nevertheless, there may be missing or incorrect data. Data may be lost or distorted as it is reported from hospitals to local, state, and federal agencies.

sections.sectionIntro: **The patients with COVID metric is the percent of staffed inpatient beds occupied by COVID patients.**

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
We source this metric directly from the CDC's community level dataset wherever possible, and calculate it ourselves using HHS provided data wherever CDC metric data isn't available. Generally, new county-level data is ingested from the CDC metrics, while all state-level data, and county-level data from before February 24th, 2022 is calculated using HHS data.

To calculate this metric for counties, we use data [from the CDC](https://data.cdc.gov/Public-Health-Surveillance/United-States-COVID-19-Community-Levels-by-County/3nnm-4jni), which uses data from the US Department of Health and Human Services Unified Hospital Data Surveillance System. To calculate this metric for metros, we aggregate the county data using a population-weighted average. To calculate this metric for states, we use data [from the HHS](https://healthdata.gov/Hospital/COVID-19-Reported-Patient-Impact-and-Hospital-Capa/g62h-syeh) to calculate the number of admissions over the last week and then normalize that by the state’s population.

questions.question: Levels
questions.answer: Levels for percentage of patients with COVID are generally based on the [CDC’s Community Level framework](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/community-levels.html). Less than 10% of all new beds is considered Low, between 10 and 14.9% is considered Medium, and greater than or equal to 15 is considered High.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
1. County-level data are only reported once a week.
2. For counties, the data is based on the [health service area](/faq#health-service-area) the county is a part of. A county with no hospitals can still have data for this metric, based on the percent of beds with COVID-19 patients in other hospitals within the health service area.

sections.sectionIntro: **Infection rate (also known as “R(t)”) is the estimated number of new people each COVID-positive person will infect.**

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
This one is a bit complicated. To calculate the infection growth, a mathematical model combines trends in daily new cases from approximately the last 14 days, with estimates for other variables, such as how many days on average occur between infection and transmission.

An R(t) of 1.0 means that the daily new cases of COVID are stable, while an R(t) greater than 1.0 means that daily new cases are growing.

To calculate the infection rate, we use new positive cases [from The New York Times](https://developer.nytimes.com/covid).

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
Because you can’t measure infection rate directly, our estimates hinge upon our epidemiological assumptions and the accuracy of our data sources. 

1. Infection rate can only track COVID growth once a positive case gets reported through the system. By then, infectious individuals have likely been COVID positive for some time, so the metric will always lag the true infection rate in the community. For example, if someone was exposed over the holidays, they likely didn’t test positive until the new year.
2. Infection rate should be considered in context with the other metrics. Daily new cases refers to the number of new COVID infections, while the infection rate represents the trend. A place with high daily new cases may have an infection rate less than 1 and still have higher exposure than a place with relatively few, but growing, cases.

questions.question: More information on infection rate
questions.answer:
[Why is infection rate important?](https://covidactnow.org/faq#infection-rate-important)

[Video explainer](https://www.youtube.com/embed/dmp5iAXrkaY)

sections.sectionIntro: **Positive test rate is the *percentage* of reported COVID PCR testing that comes back positive** **(not the total number of positive PCR tests).**

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
Positive test rate is calculated by dividing the number of positive reported PCR tests over the last 7 days by the total number of reported PCR tests over the last 7 days. It should be looked at in conjunction with other metrics such as infection rate and new cases.

We source state level testing data from the [Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)](https://healthdata.gov/dataset/COVID-19-Diagnostic-Laboratory-Testing-PCR-Testing/j8mb-icvb) and county/metro level testing data from the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Covid Data Tracker](https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#county-view). Check out your location’s page for more details.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
Federal data sets such as the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) attempt to standardize fragmented testing data by representing diagnostic specimens and excluding non-PCR tests. However there are limitations due to some states reporting testing data differently.

1. While we try to strictly use PCR tests, it’s possible that some states combine [PCR](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#pcr-test) and rapid testing.
2. Some states track positive tests while others track people who test positive. So someone who takes three tests and eventually tests positive may be counted in noticeably different ways depending on whether the state tracks tests, people, or encounters.

questions.question: More information on positive test rate
questions.answer:
[What does positive test rate tell us?](https://covidactnow.org/faq#what-does-positive-test-rate-tell-us)

[Video explainer](https://www.youtube.com/embed/RpqI-ZVGGoY)

sections.sectionIntro: **ICU capacity used measures the number of intensive care unit (ICU) beds that are currently in use.**

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
We calculate ICU capacity by taking the number of staffed ICU beds that are occupied (by both COVID and Non-COVID patients) and dividing it by the total number of staffed ICU beds. We use data from the [Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)](https://healthdata.gov/Hospital/COVID-19-Reported-Patient-Impact-and-Hospital-Capa/g62h-syeh) to calculate the metric. This data is provided to the HHS via three sources: (1) HHS TeleTracking, (2) reporting provided directly to HHS Protect by state/territorial health departments on behalf of their healthcare facilities and (3) National Healthcare Safety Network (before July 15). For counties we aggregate the data for all counties in the [health service area](/faq#health-service-area).

For more details, see the Trends module.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
This data is closely watched by HHS, but nevertheless, there may be missing or incorrect data. Data may be lost or distorted as it is reported from hospitals to local, state, and federal agencies, such as the HHS. 

The biggest source of uncertainty in this metric is the ability for a hospital to quickly expand beyond its normal capacity to meet increased demand. This “[surge” capacity](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#surge-capacity) is difficult to predict in advance because it depends on both physical hospital resources like available beds and non-physical resources like healthy nurses and doctors to run them.

HHS tries to control for this by requiring that hospitals report staffed ICU beds on a daily basis, but this doesn’t give a complete picture about theoretical surge capacity.

sections.sectionIntro: **% Vaccinated is the percentage of the total population in a given location that has started the vaccination process.**

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
Our vaccination metric tracks the percentage of the total population in each location that has initiated vaccination, not limited to those who are 5 and older. Someone has initiated vaccination if they have received the first shot of any of the currently available vaccines (Pfizer, Moderna, J&J). We also track the percentage of people who have completed 2+ doses of Pfizer or Moderna or the single dose J&J vaccine, and the percentage of people who have received a booster shot.

Our primary source for state and county vaccination data is the [CDC COVID Data Tracker](https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations). For certain states and counties where CDC data coverage is low we source data from state and county public health dashboards.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
The vaccination data we show contains a number of limitations: 

1. **Vaccine vs. infection-acquired immunity**: We focus on vaccine-acquired immunity and do not account for infection-acquired immunity. At this time, we are not sufficiently confident in the ability to estimate vaccine-acquired plus infection-acquired immunity. We will revisit this choice if the CDC puts out more information about general seroprevalence and the infection history of people getting vaccinated.
2. **Vaccine variations**: We treat all vaccine manufacturers equally, e.g. our data combines people who have received the Pfizer, Moderna, and J&J vaccines. We will re-evaluate this with any additional data, especially as more types of vaccines become available. 
3. **Timeliness**: We get our national and state data from the CDC, which does not always update daily. There are currently unavoidable delays from the provider to the CDC and from the CDC to the public.
4. **Underestimation of booster shots and overestimation of primary dose:** If a booster is administered in a different location than the primary vaccine series, the CDC may report the booster shot as a first dose in some instances.

County-level vaccination data can suffer from additional limitations including:

1. **Lack of 1st dose data:** For rare cases where county-level 1st dose data is unavailable, we estimate 1st dose vaccinations based on the ratio of first dose and second dose (or J&J) vaccinations at the state level.
2. **Under-reporting**: If a vaccine is administered within a state but accurate county of residence information is not collected then the vaccination cannot be attributed to any specific county, leading to under-reporting.
3. **Misattribution**: Some vaccinations may be attributed to the county of administration rather than the county of residence, leading to over and under-reporting.
4. **Missing federally-administered doses:** Doses administered through federal programs (e.g. Indian Health Services, Department of Defense, Bureau of Prisons, and Veterans Affairs) are sometimes not included in state-reported vaccination numbers leading to under-reporting.

sections.sectionIntro:
**Communities with higher vulnerability have pre-existing economic, social, and physical conditions that may make it hard to respond to and recover from a COVID outbreak.**

As of January 2022, people in the *most* vulnerable third of U.S. counties are 38 percent more likely to have died from COVID than people in the *least* vulnerable third of U.S. counties ([see source](https://precisionforcovid.org/ccvi)).  

This is due to a number of factors such as a community members’ income, age, and underlying health, as well as their access to transportation and health care.

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
We use a score calculated by [Surgo Ventures](https://precisionforcovid.org/ccvi), a nonprofit with expertise in behavioral and data science. Known as the COVID-19 Community Vulnerability Index (CCVI), this index compares states, counties, and metros across the U.S. and ranks their vulnerability relative to each other, for example with the least vulnerable county assigned a score of 0 percent, and the most vulnerable county in the U.S. with a score of 100 percent, meaning it is more vulnerable than 100 of counties in the U.S. A location’s vulnerability score looks at seven different factors: 

* **Unemployment & low income**: Financial insecurity, lack of access to health care, or the inability to work remotely or with protections and benefits increases vulnerability to severe COVID outcomes.
* **Minorities & non-English speakers**: Language barriers can restrict access to public health messaging and resources. Data on COVID has demonstrated that racial and ethnic minorities are often at the highest risk of poor medical outcomes.
* **Housing & transport challenges**: Crowded housing, housing insecurity, access to indoor plumbing and limited transit options make it more difficult to avoid COVID exposure.
* **Older age & health issues**: High-risk groups (per CDC guidelines) such as elderly adults or people with pre-existing conditions have experienced more severe health outcomes throughout the pandemic.
* **Health system challenges**: Hospital bed availability, access to pharmacies, and the amount of healthcare spending per capita within a region, among other factors, can indicate the limited capacity of healthcare systems to respond to COVID.
* **Crowded living & working areas**: High-risk environments, such as prisons, nursing homes, or factories, significantly contribute to a person's exposure to and vulnerability to the virus.
* **Population density**: Higher population density has been demonstrated to increase the risk of quick viral spread and adverse health outcomes. Given its importance in understanding vulnerability to the pandemic, it comprises a specific theme in the index.

Surgo Ventures sources their data from the CDC, Centers for Medicare, & Medicaid Services (CMS), the Harvard Global Health Institute, PolicyMap, the U.S Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), the U.S. Census Bureau (USCB), the National Cancer Institute (NCI), the National Center for HIV, STD and TB Prevention (NCHSTP), Kaiser Health News, Census Economic Annual Surveys, the Vera institute for Justice, and the Association of Public Health Laboratories (APHL).

The CCVI is updated whenever new research about risk factors for COVID becomes available. Thus far it's been updated approximately every 4-6 months, but this may change. The way the CCVI is calculated may also change in the future, for instance to take into account economic recovery.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
Vulnerability is a complex issue, and it does not look the same in every community and through every lens. There are several limitations of the CCVI data to keep in mind: 

* The index is an estimate of vulnerability and does not account for every factor which may make an individual or community at higher risk of COVID disease or death. 
* For the most complete understanding of a community’s vulnerability, the index should be used in conjunction with COVID statistics and data on public response, such as test site locations, [nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs)](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#npi), and vaccine distribution. 
* The CCVI may not capture all at-risk essential worker groups represented in the “crowded living and working areas” special vulnerability.

questions.question: Still have more questions?
questions.answer: For further details, read [](https://docs.google.com/document/d/142EPwY0GqcSJlsD2fJOHIg_2G4e2ksxy8iToJ7maP4Y/edit)[Surgo’s methodology and sourcing document](https://covid-static-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/US-CCVI/COVID-19+Community+Vulnerability+Index+(CCVI)+Methodology.pdf).

sections.sectionIntro:
Until Spring of 2022 when the CDC released their [community level framework](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/community-levels.html), Covid Act Now used three key metrics to assess a location's overall risk level—**daily new cases** (incidence), **infection rate** (RT) and **positive test rate**. The other three metrics—**ICU capacity used**, **% vaccinated** and **vulnerability**—reflected a location's ability to protect itself and recover from COVID. Below, learn more about each metric and how it was assessed.

A state or county’s overall risk level took into account three metrics: daily new cases per 100K (incidence), infection rate (Rt), and test positivity. 

* **Daily new cases**, also known as “incidence” in epidemiology, represents the current amount of COVID in a community. 
* **Infection rate** is the direction and speed of growth. For instance, daily new cases may be low, but if infection rate is high, then we know that daily new cases will be high in the near future. 
* **Positive test rate** is a measure of confidence in the underlying data. For instance, if daily new cases and infection rate are both low, but test positivity is high, then the lack of sufficient testing suggests that we are not capturing the true levels of COVID and both daily new cases and infection rate are actually higher than what is currently reported. 

If a region’s daily new cases was green, then its overall risk level was green. Otherwise, a region’s overall risk level reflected the highest risk level across all three metrics.

sections.sectionHeader: Covid Act Now's former risk levels

pageIntro:
As of April 2022, Covid Act Now follows a 3-color COVID community risk level framework informed by 3 key metrics: 

* **Cases**: (weekly new reported cases per 100k)
* **Admissions**: (weekly COVID admissions per 100k)
* **Patients**: (% of patients with COVID of all beds).

This new framework replaces our former “U.S. COVID Risk Level” to better reflect the now decreased risk of severe illness and death from COVID due to vaccines, therapeutics, and past COVID infections, as well as other developments. 

It’s based on the CDC’s [Community Level framework](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/community-levels.html) and its recommendations, which prioritize reducing severe illness and death, and preventing healthcare systems from being overwhelmed. Its aim is to help communities across the country live safely with the coronavirus, while also, as much as possible, returning to some version of normal life. 

We are not afraid to diverge from the CDC and other frameworks, and have done so repeatedly in the past. Our objective is to provide our users with the most accurate, accessible, and actionable COVID data available. Fortunately, after evaluating the CDC’s latest framework independently and carefully with our Medical Board of Advisors, we believe it better reflects the latest state of the pandemic and have decided to align our products with it. 

That said, we understand that there are some who are concerned about contracting COVID despite the reduced chances of severe illness and death, such as those who are immunocompromised, have unvaccinated children, or are concerned about long COVID. People who need extra caution can still make decisions using our older metrics, which now fall under the category of **Transmission levels**: 

* Daily new cases
* Infection rate 
* Positive test rate

Those metrics are still available on our site for each location and in our API. Just bear in mind that these metrics are, as previously stated, calculated using test results that do not capture unreported at-home tests that are increasingly used.
